titleStmt.title: Triglycerides and carotid intima-media thickness in ischemic stroke patients

affiliation.orgName: Department for Biostatistics and Clinical Epidemiology

analytic.title: Triglycerides and carotid intima-media thickness in ischemic stroke patients

biblStruct.note: Received 9 September 2014 Received in revised form 26 August 2015 Accepted 3 September 2015

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Glucose Triglycerides Intima-media thickness Acute stroke Ultrasonography

p.s: Background: Common carotid artery intima-media thickness (CCA-IMT) is an established marker for atherosclerosis.
The role of triglycerides in CCA-IMT remains controversial.
We sought to determine if elevated fasting and post-challenge triglycerides are associated with CCA-IMT.

Methods: All acute ischemic stroke patients who participated in the Berlin "Cream & Sugar" study in the Charit e Virchow and Charit e Mitte Campuses between January 2009 and January 2014 and underwent carotid artery ultrasound studies were eligible for inclusion.
A combined oral glucose and triglyceride tolerance test was performed 3e7 days after first ever ischemic stroke.

Patients were classified according to triglyceride metabolismdnamely, (1) patients reaching a maximum triglyceride levels 3 h postchallenge ("fast metabolizers," n ¼ 37), (2) patients with increasing triglycerides 4 (medium metabolizers, n ¼ 64), and (3) 5 h post-challenge ("slow metabolizers," n ¼ 44; 13 missing).
Results: We included 158 patients (34% female; mean age 63 years, SD 14).
Absolute non-fasting triglyceride levels were positively associated with CCA-IMT.
A final multiple regression model revealed that older age, more severe strokes, and higher levels of fasting triglycerides were significantly and independently associated with higher mean CCA-IMT.
Older age, higher waist-to-hip ratio, and higher levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone were independently associated with higher maximum CCA-IMT.
Conclusion: Fasting triglycerides but not post-challenge triglycerides associate with CCA-IMT.
An oral fat challenge may not add information on atherosclerotic status in ischemic stroke patients.
Clinical Trial Registration Information: The Berlin "Cream & Sugar" study is registered with EudraCT (2009-010356-97) and clinicaltrials.gov
Common carotid artery intima-media thickness (CCA-IMT) is an established marker of atherosclerosis [1] and ischemic stroke risk [2,3].

Though impaired postprandial triglyceride clearance has long been thought to contribute to coronary atherosclerosis [4e6], surprisingly few studies have directly investigated the relationship between CCA-IMT and triglyceride metabolism [7e11].
Results from studies that have assessed the relationship between absolute triglycerides and CCA-IMT have been mixed.
Some studies have found positive relationships to exist between CCA-IMT and postprandial [7e10] or fasting triglycerides [12e14].
Others have found no association to exist between CCA-IMT and fasting [15e17] or post-challenge triglycerides [11].
To date, most trials assessing triglyceride reduction strategies in patients with high cardiovascular risk profiles have used fasting levels when screening patients for inclusion [18e20].
However, evidence from large epidemiological studies shows that nonfasting triglycerides are likely more indicative of cardiovascular risk [21,22].

Therefore, it is possible that patient samples in trials with triglyceride lowering endpoints have not been optimally selected, which has led to the suggestion that implementing a standardized oral triglyceride tolerance test may be beneficial when screening patients for cardiovascular/stroke risk [23].
We sought to determine if fasting and post-challenge triglycerides associate with CCA-IMT in ischemic stroke patients.
The Berlin "Cream & Sugar" study (NCT 01378468) is an ongoing prospective cohort study with the purpose of determining if postchallenge triglycerides associate with recurrent stroke.
Detailed methods have been presented elsewhere [24].

Briefly, we screened all suspected stroke patients within 3e7 days of symptom onset who were over 18 years of age and were admitted to one of three university campus hospitals in Berlin (Charit e Mitte, Virchow, and Benjamin Franklin campuses).
First ever acute ischemic stroke patients who were capable of participating in an oral triglyceride and glucose tolerance test were eligible for inclusion.
Ischemic stroke was defined as a focal neurological deficit lasting for at least 24 h with no signs of hemorrhage on cerebral imaging.
All strokes were verified radiologically using diffusionweighted images.
First ever ischemic stroke was defined based on relevant medical history disregarding potential "silent" strokes on cerebral imaging that may have occurred prior to study enrollment.
Stroke severity was assessed on hospital admission and on the day of testing (3e7 days after symptom onset) using the National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS).
Stroke was categorized according to a mechanism-based classification scheme (Trial of ORG 10172 in Acute Stroke Treatment, or TOAST) [25].
All patients provided informed consent and the study was approved by the local ethics committee.
Baseline data and venous blood samples were collected after participants had provided informed consent and fasted overnight for !10 h.
Fasting blood samples were drawn at 8 AM, followed by a combined oral triglyceride and glucose tolerance test (oTTT/oGTT).
The oTTT consisted of ingesting 250 mL of 32% fat cream within 30 min and took place immediately after the 8 AM fasting blood draw.
At 11 AM, all patients provided venous blood samples and if no known diabetes was present, patients then immediately drank 75 g of Dextrose mixed in 250 mL of water (oral glucose tolerance test).
Further venous blood samples were collected at 12 PM and 1 PM.
Triglyceride and cholesterol concentrations were determined in freshly drawn venous blood samples enzymatically using a Cobas 6000 analyzer (Roche/Hitachi).
In this Berlin "Cream & Sugar" substudy, we searched our clinical database for CCA ultrasound images archived in the Virchow and Mitte Campuses.

CCA ultrasounds were performed by our clinical neurology sonography lab using B-mode ultrasonography with the Acuson X300 (Siemens Healthcare, Germany; Virchow) and the Toshiba PowerVision 6000 (Toshiba, Japan; Mitte) 7.5 MHz high-resolution annular array scanner.
All patients were evaluated in the supine position with the head turned 45 to the contralateral side of the artery being examined.
One rater (KSL) evaluated CCA-IMT using the ImageJ software package (National Institute of Health, Baltimore, Md) [26].
Both the right and left CCA were evaluated.
All measurements were performed in accordance with the "Mannheim carotid intima-media thickness consensus" (2004e2006) [27].
The region of interest (ROI) for CCA-IMT assessment was defined as at least a 10 mm plaque-free portion of the CCA far-wall at least 10 mm before the bifurcation.

As illustrated in Fig. 1, to determine CCA-IMT, we measured the distance between the first hyperechogenic line (border between vessel lumen and intima, yellow line in Fig. 1) and the second hyperechogenic line (mediaeadventitia border, pink line in Fig. 1) of the CCA far wall.

To assess associations between various patient characteristics and CCA-IMT, we used aggregated values per patient using two different aggregation methods: (1) maximum recorded CCA-IMT value (i.e. if the right CCA-IMT was larger than the left CCA-IMT, the right CCA-IMT value was used) and (2) mean CCA-IMT value of the right and left CCA.
The number of heart cycles and time-point within the heart cycle was not taken into consideration.
Diabetes was defined as current use of anti-diabetic medication or serum glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1C) of >6.5%.
Hypertension was defined as current antihypertensive medication use.
Glomerular filtration rate was estimated using the Modification of Diet and Renal Diseases formula [28].

Adjusted triglyceride levels for 3, 4, and 5 h post-challenge (aTG3, aTG4, aTG5) were defined here as the triglyceride values at 3, 4, and 5 h post-challenge minus the fasting triglyceride value (TG0) respectively (e.g.
aTG3 ¼ TG3 À TG0).
Peak triglyceride response refers to the maximum triglyceride level obtained minus TG0.
Triglyceride area under the curve (AUC) and incremental area under the curve (iAUC; relative to fasting triglyceride values) were calculated using the trapezoidal integration method.
"Fast" triglyceride metabolizers was defined here as having triglyceride values that rose sharply from 0 to 3 h postchallenge and thereafter declined.
"Medium" triglyceride metabolism was defined as having reached maximum triglyceride values between 3 and 4 h post-challenge.
"Slow" triglyceride metabolism indicates triglyceride levels that rose until 5 h post-challenge.

For all metabolism categories (fast, medium, and slow), a "rise" in triglyceride levels (or "maximum" triglyceride level) was defined as a >10% increase in triglyceride values from one consecutive timepoint to the next (e.g.
fasting to 3 h post-challenge; 3 he4 h postchallenge, and 4e5 h post-challenge).

To present bivariate descriptive characteristics, CCA-IMT (dependent variable) was stratified into tertiles (three equal groups) and ordinal regression analyses were performed using individual continuous variables separately as independent variables (Table 1).
Non-normally distributed variables were logtransformed (log 10) to reduce skewness before analyses.
To test differences in CCA-IMT between different categorical characteristics ManneWhitney-Test or KruskaleWallis-Test was used (Table 2).
With regard to ordinal characteristics, ordinal regression analyses were performed with the ordinal variable set as the dependent variable.
Post hoc pairwise comparisons among estimated marginal means (adjusted for age categories) were conducted to assess differences in CCA-IMT with regard to triglyceride metabolism.
Variables significant at the a-level of 0.10 in bivariate analysis were included into a backwards stepwise multiple linear regression analysis with log-transformed CCA-IMT as dependent variable.
Collinearity was assessed by calculating tolerance (considered significant if < 0.2) and variance inflation factor (considered relevant collinearity if > 5).
All statistical analyses were performed with SPSS 22 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, USA).
All tests were 2sided and, unless otherwise stated, relationships were considered significant at an a-level of 0.05.
No adjustment for multiple testing was applied.

We included 158 patients in this Berlin "Cream & Sugar" substudy (please see Supplemental Figure S1 for overall summary of "Cream & Sugar" sample size during screening, inclusion/exclusion, and analysis for this sub-study).

In comparison with the overall Cream & Sugar study cohort, the patient sample included in this sub-study was significantly younger (median 65 years, IQR: 51e73; remaining C&S cohort: median 68 years, IQR: 57e75; Man-neWhitney U: p ¼ 0.018), had lower serum creatinine values (included: median 0.88 mg/dL, IQR: 74e1.01;
remaining C&S cohort: median 0.94 mg/dL, IQR: 0.8e1.05;

ManneWhitney U: For mean CCA-IMT values, backwards stepwise multiple linear regression analysis (which included 82 patients) that tested for variables significant at an a-level of 0.10 in bivariate analysisdi.e., age, stroke severity (according to NIHSS), waist-to-hip ratio, systolic blood pressure, estimated glomerular filtration rate (according to MDRD), stroke subtype (according to TOAST classification), triglyceride metabolism, statins, and ace inhibitor medicationdrevealed associations between higher mean CCA-IMT (i.e.

mean of left and right CCA, log-transformed) and older age (unstandardized b ¼ 0.0003, p < 0.001), more severe strokes (logtransformed NIHSS, unstandardized b ¼ 0.035, p ¼ 0.015), and higher levels of fasting triglycerides (log-transformed, unstandardized b ¼ 0.012, p ¼ 0.018).
Only these three covariates remained in the final model.
No evidence for collinearity was found.

For maximum CCA-IMT values (log-transformed), backwards stepwise multiple linear regression analysis (which included 127 patients) that tested for variables significant at an a-level of 0.10 in bivariate analysisdi.e., age, waist-to-hip ratio, CRP, estimated glomerular filtration rate (according to MDRD), thyroid-stimulating hormone, insulin resistance (according to HOMA), and stroke subtype (according to TOAST classification)drevealed that higher maximum CCA-IMT values (log-transformed) were associated with older age (unstandardized b ¼ 0.004, p < 0.001), higher waist-tohip ratio (log-transformed, unstandardized b ¼ 0.475, p ¼ 0.023), and higher levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (log-transformed, unstandardized b ¼ 0.082, p ¼ 0.042).
Only the variables with reported regression coefficients remained in the final model.
No evidence for collinearity was identified.
We additionally analyzed parameters associated with plaque presence (present vs. not present).
Retrospective analysis showed that plaque presence was associated with higher HbA1c (present: median HbA1c 5.7%, IQR 5.4e6.3;
not present: median HbA1c 5.3%, IQR 5.0e5.6,
ManneWhitney U test, p ¼ 0.001), waist-to-hip ratio (plaques: median 0.98, IQR 0.95e1.03;
no plaques: median 0.94, IQR 0.88e0.99,

ManneWhitney U test, p ¼ 0.027), 5-h postchallenge triglycerides (plaques: median 246 mg/dL, IQR 166e356; no plaques: median 214 mg/dL, IQR 110e255, Man-neWhitney U test, p ¼ 0.05), fasting glucose (plaques: median 98 mg/dL, IQR 88e113; no plaques: median 88 mg/dL, IQR 85e95, ManneWhitney U test, p ¼ 0.003).

Additionally, plaques presence was significantly associated with a lower estimate glomerular filtration rate (plaques: median 84 mL/min, IQR 71e97; no plaques: median 103 mL/min, IQR 84e111, ManneWhitney U test, p ¼ 0.009)
The main finding of this study was that fasting triglycerides independently and positively associated with mean CCA-IMT in acute ischemic stroke patients.

This contributes to the current literature as it extends the observation that though the link between absolute triglyceride levels (whether fasting or non-fasting) may be tenuous, triglyceride exposure seems to play at least an associative role in atherogenesis.
Based on these results however, we cannot recommend using an oral triglyceride tolerance test to identify patients at high risk for atherosclerosis.
Currently, the understanding is that circulating triglycerides largely arise from dietary fat intake [29].

Traditionally not considered to be atherogenic due to their large size, more recent findings in mice genetically bread to be incapable of performing lipolysis on the luminal side of the endothelium have shown that chylomicronemia (and resultant severe hypertriglyceridemia) leads to atherosclerotic lesions [30].
It remains unclear why this is the case, though it has been speculated that macrophages and proinflammatory factors may play a contributing role [31].
Additionally, in humans, it has been proposed that prolonged exposure to elevated triglycerides may alter endothelial metabolism and predispose for atherosclerotic changes [32].

Though we found that fasting triglycerides associate with atherosclerotic burden in the CCA, our findings oppose this newer theory that prolonged postchallenge triglyceride exposure is associated with CCA-IMT.
Recently published results from the Homburg Cream and Sugar study [33] augment our findings.

Using identical oral triglyceride tolerance test methods in patients with coronary artery disease, Werner et al. found that elevated serum triglycerides (fasting and area under the curve) independently associated with cardiovascular events.
Similarly, Werner et al. found that post-challenge triglycerides were not superior to fasting triglycerides in outcome prediction models.
Akin to these findings, we observed that initial stroke severity (assessed using the NIHSS scale) and fasting triglycerides associated independently with CCA-IMT in ischemic stroke patients.
Additionally, Schmidt-Trucks€ ass et al. [34] found that certain triglyceride profiles tended to be atherogenic in that they had higher LDL and lower HDL cholesterol.

Specifically, they classified patients as: Group 1 ("low risk"), patients who had both fasting and post-challenge triglycerides of <200 mg/dL; Group 2 ("moderate risk"), patients with fasting triglycerides <200 mg/dL and maximum post-challenge triglycerides >200 mg/dL; and Group 3 ("high risk"), patients whose fasting and maximum post-challenge triglycerides were >200 mg/dL.

We retrospectively stratified our patients according to this scheme and found that although none of the groups associated with CCA-IMT or carotid plaques (data not shown), there was a positive linear association between the triglyceride groups and LDL (ordinal regression, LDL log transformed, unstandardized beta 0.011, p ¼ 0.031) and total cholesterol (ordinal regression, unstandardized beta 0.012, p ¼ 0.006).
This stratification of triglycerides warrants further investigation as it may pertain to functional stroke outcome and recurrent stroke.
It has been speculated that vascular risk might be best assessed 3e4 h (i.e. during peak time points) following a triglyceride tolerance test [23].
We observed that post-challenge triglyceride concentrations increased similarly in all patients until roughly the 4 h post-challenge time-points.
These findings akin to those of Groot et al. [4], who measured triglyceride concentrations for 24 h following an oral triglyceride tolerance test in patients with and without coronary artery disease.

Although Groot et al. [4] reported an association between coronary artery disease and 8 h triglycerides and later, graphical representation revealed that the groups began to deviate between the 4 and 5 h time-points (though not of statistical significance).
This study has limitations.
First, because of Berlin "Cream & Sugar" Study inclusion criteria, there was a selection bias for mildly affected stroke patients (median NIHSS 1; range 0e13).
Second, men were overrepresented (71%).
Third, our study sample was relatively small and our cross-sectional approach limits our ability to identify a cause-effect relationship between triglyceride metabolism and CCA-IMT.
Larger, longitudinal studies are needed to assess the possible relationship we found here.
Fourth, we did not take the time-point of CCA-IMT measurement during the heart cycle into account.
Finally, a large number of patients were taking statins (51%), which may have influenced our lipid metabolism parameters.
However, we controlled for statin use in multiple models and the relationship between CCA-IMT and fasting triglycerides remained significant.
In conclusion, we found that fasting serum triglycerides positively and independently associate with CCA-IMT.
Post-challenge triglycerides however, were not associated with CCA-IMT.
The novel combined oral glucose and triglyceride tolerance test was not efficacious in selecting patients with increased atherosclerotic burden.
Fig. 1.
Ultrasound and schematic representation of the common carotid artery.
In the schematic representation, the yellow line represents the luminal intima and the pink line represents the adventitia.
The space between the adventitia and intima on the far wall of the CCA is defined here as the intima-media thickness.
CCA indicates common carotid artery; IMT, intima-media thickness; ROI, region of interest; min, minimum; mm, millimeters.
(For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)
Baseline characteristics of continuous variables according to mean (of right and left artery) common carotid intima-media thickness tertiles.

ALAT indicates alanine aminotransferase; BMI, body mass index; CRP, c-reactive protein; dBP, diastolic blood pressure; eGFR, estimated glomerular filtration rate; GLC0-4, glucose level (0, fasting; 3, 3 h post-challenge; 4, 4 h post-challenge; 5, 5 h post-challenge); HbA1c, glycosylated hemoglobin; HDL, high density lipoprotein; HOMA, Homeostasis Model Assessment; IMT, common carotid intima-media thickness; LDL, low density lipoprotein; mg/dL, milligrams per deciliter; min, minute; mL, milliliters; mm, millimeters; mmHg, millimeter of mercury; mmol/L, millimoles per Liter; NIHSS, National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale; Peak TGr, peak triglyceride response (¼triglyceride maximum e fasting triglyceride); WHR, TG0eTG5, triglycerides (0, fasting; 3, 5 indicate number of hours post-challenge); TG AUC, triglyceride area under the curve; TG iAUC, triglyceride incremental area under the curve; waist-to-hip ratio.a
Covariate normally distributed.
Values reported are mean (standard deviation); p-values generated from ordinal regression analysis.
b Covariate not normally distributed.

Values reported are median (interquartile range); p-values generated from ordinal regression analysis with covariate log 10 (included: median 133 mg/dL, IQR: 75e207; remaining C&S cohort: median 101 mg/dL, IQR: 58e104; ManneWhitney U: p < 0.001), lower statin use (45% included vs. 62% cohort; Chi Squared: p ¼ 0.003), and tended to have lower hypertension rates (55% included vs. 64% cohort; Chi Squared: p ¼ 0.063).
No other significant differences in baseline characteristics were observed.
The mean age of patients included in this sub-study (n ¼ 158;
Baseline characteristics of categorical variables across mean (of right and left artery) common carotid intima-media thickness values.

row.cell: Antag indicates antagonist; ARA II, angiotensin receptor 2 antagonists; ACE,
angiotensin converting enzyme; CAD, coronary artery disease; IMTmean, common
carotid intima-media thickness, average thickness between right and left artery;
IQR, interquartile range; Monotx, monotherapy; NA, not applicable; TG, tri-
glycerides; TOAST, Trial of Org 10172 in Acute Stroke Treatment.
b Ordinal regression (intima-media thickness log transformed).

p.s: The research leading to these results has received funding from the Federal Ministry of Education and Research via the grant Center for Stroke Research Berlin (01 E0 0801).
None to declare.
JB, CL, UG, KSL, SJS, and Martin E have no conflicts of interest to declare.

Matthias E has received grant support from AstraZeneca and Sanofi, has participated in advisory board meetings of Bayer, Boehringer Ingelheim, Bristol-Myers Squibb, MSD, Pfizer, Sanofi and has received honoraria from Astra Zeneca, Bayer, Berlin Chemie, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Boehringer-Ingelheim, Desitin, Eisei, Ever, Glaxo Smith Kline, MSD, Novartis, Pfizer, Sanofi, Takeda, Trommsdorff.
Supplementary data related to this article can be found at http:// dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.atherosclerosis.2015.09.003.
